member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Client.FlioxClient
member.summary:
Application classes extending offer two main functionalities:
1. Define a database schema by declaring its containers, commands and messages
2. Its instances are database clients providing type-safe access to database containers, commands and messages
member.remarks:
Its containers are fields or properties of type .
Its commands are methods returning a .
Its messages are methods returning a .
instances can be used in server and client code.
The features and utilization available at Client README.md
Info: A single instance support multiple parallel async operations executed with .
E.g. multiple can be called without immediate await and instead using Task.WhenAll() for all tasks.

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Client.FlioxClient.SyncTasks
member.summary: Execute all tasks created by methods of and
member.remarks:

As an alternative use to execute tasks which does not throw an exception.
The method can be called without awaiting the result of a previous call.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Client.EntitySet`2
member.summary:
An EntitySet represents a collection (table) of entities (records) of type and their key type .
The methods of an enable to create, read, upsert, delete, patch and aggregate container entities.
It also allows to subscribe to entity changes made by other database clients.
member.remarks:
's are designed to be used as fields or properties inside a .
The type of a container entity need to be a class containing a field or property used as its key - the primary key.
This key field is usually named id. Using a different name for the primary key requires the field annotation [Key].
Supported types are: , , , , and . The type of must match the used for the [Key] field / property in an entity class. In case of a type mismatch a runtime exceptions is thrown.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Client.SubscriptionEventHandler
member.summary: Defines the signature of the event handler passed to
member.remarks:
All subscription handler methods are synchronous by intention.
Reason: In contrast to handler methods of a service or a web server subscription handlers don't return a result.
In case the application need to call an asynchronous method consider using the approach below:
Task.Factory.StartNew(() => AsyncMethod());
Note: exceptions thrown in the AsyncMethod() are unhandled. Add try/catch to log exceptions.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.DB.UserAuth.UserAuthenticator
member.summary:
Performs user authentication by validating the user and token of every request
Performs authorization for successful authenticated users by applying their assigned permissions.

list.item:
To avoid loosing access to the Hub accidentally following operations are not permitted:
- Delete user admin
- Change permission admin
- Change role hub-admin
The permission .all-users - if available - is used for authenticated and anonymous users.

User permissions and roles are transparently defined and stored in the user_db.
So authorization is fully documented by these two containers.

User permissions and roles are cached for successful authenticated users.
This enables instant task authorization and reduces the number of reads to the user_db significant.

member.summary: Set default admin permissions records in the user database to enable Hub access with user admin.
member.remarks:
- create user credential: admin if not exist
- set user permission: admin with role hub-admin
- set role: hub-admin granting full access to all databases
This enables access to all Hub databases as user admin without accessing the user database directly.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.DatabaseServiceQueue
member.summary:
A can be used by a to queue execution of all commands and messages.
To execute queued commands the application needs to call on a regular basis.
This enables synchronous execution of requests / commands / tasks on the main thread used in game loops.
As a result states or resources used / mutated by commands can be performed without any expensive thread synchronization mechanisms.
Note: is not appropriate for a typical server application as they are not intended to have a 'main thread' which would be the bottle neck for high concurrency.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.EntityContainer
member.summary: An is the abstraction of a collection / table used to store entities / records as key value pairs.
member.remarks:
It uses a string as key and a JSON object as value. Each container is intended to store the entities / records of a specific type. E.g. one container for storing JSON objects representing 'articles' another one for storing 'orders'.
define the entire set of interfaces a database adapter needs to implement to enable the complete feature set of and . and all its implementations must be thread safe.
The interface methods are designed to enable clear, compact and efficient implementations of database operations. E.g. operations like SELECT, INSERT, DELETE or UPDATE in case of an SQL database adapter. , and CosmosContainer show straight forward implementation of . Additional to memory implementation shows also how to handle database errors. These errors fall into two categories:
1. A complete database request fails. E.g. a SELECT in SQL. => need to be set.
2. The database request was successful, but one or more entities (key/values) had an error when accessing. E.g. Writing an entity to a file with a fails because it is used by another process. => An need to be added to task result errors. E.g. add an error to in case of
All ...Result types returned by the interface methods of like , , ... implement . In case a database command fails completely needs to be set. See for proper error handling.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.EntityDatabase
member.summary: is the abstraction for specific database adapter / implementation e.g. a or .
member.remarks:
An contains multiple 's each representing a table / collection of a database. Each container is intended to store the records / entities of a specific type. E.g. one container for storing JSON objects representing 'articles' another one for storing 'orders'.
Optionally a can be assigned to the database via the property . This enables Type / schema validation of JSON entities written (create, update and patch) to its containers.
Instances of and all its implementation are designed to be thread safe enabling multiple clients e.g. operating on the same instance - used by a . To maintain thread safety implementations must not have any mutable state.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.FileDatabase
member.summary: A is used to store the entities / records of its containers as JSON files in the file-system.
member.remarks:
Each database container / table is a sub folder of the path passed to the constructor.
The intention of a is providing out of the box persistence without the need of installation or configuration of a third party database server like: SQLite, Postgres, ...
This enables the following uses cases
Creating proof-of-concept database applications without any third party dependencies
Suitable for TDD as test records are JSON files versioned via Git and providing access to their change history
Using a database without configuration by using a relative database path within a project
Viewing and editing database records as JSON files with text editors like VSCode, vi, web browsers, ...
Using a as data source to seed other databases with
In most uses cases a in not suitable for production as its read / write performance cannot compete with databases like: SQLite, Postgres, ... .
has no third party dependencies.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.FlioxHub
member.summary: A act as a Proxy between a or a web browser and an .
member.remarks:
The features and utilization is available at Host README.md
When creating a a default is assigned to the instance and all tasks requested by a client are applied to this .
A can be configured to support:
Pub-Sub to send events of database changes or messages to clients by assigning an to .
Note: A client need to subscribe events in order to receive them.
User authentication and task authorization. Each task is authorized individually.
To enable this assign a to .
Monitoring of database access (requests) by adding a with .
A instance handle all client requests by its method.
A request is represented by a and its are executed on the given .
If database == null the default of is used.
The contains all database operations like create, read, upsert, delete and all messages / commands send by a client.
The execute these tasks by the of the specified .
Instances of are thread-safe enabling multiple clients e.g. operating on the same instance.
To maintain thread safety implementations must not have any mutable state.

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.FlioxHub.ExecuteRequestAsync(Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Protocol.SyncRequest,Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.SyncContext)
member.summary:
Execute all of a send by client.
Method is thread-safe as multiple instances are allowed to use a single instance.
member.remarks:
All requests to a are handled by this method. By design this is the 'front door' all requests have to pass to get processed.
catches exceptions thrown by a but this is only a fail safe mechanism. Thrown exceptions need to be handled by proper error handling in the first place.
Reasons for the design decision:
a) Without a proper error handling the root cause of an error cannot be traced back.
b) Exceptions are expensive regarding CPU utilization and heap allocation.
An exception can have two different reasons:
1. The implementation of an is missing a proper error handling. A proper error handling requires to set a meaningful to
2. An issue in the namespace which must to be fixed.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.MemoryDatabase
member.summary: A is a non-persistent database used to store records in memory.
member.remarks:
The intention is having a shared database which can be used in high performance scenarios. E.g:
4 Core i7-4790K CPU 4.00GHz: 1.000.000 requests / second.
Mac Mini M2: 1.800.000 requests / second.
Following use-cases are suitable for a
Run a big amount of unit tests fast and efficient as instantiation of take only some micro seconds.
Use as a Game Session database for online multiplayer games as it provide sub millisecond response latency
Use as test database for TDD without any configuration
Is the benchmark reference for all other database implementations regarding throughput and latency
has no third party dependencies. Storage characteristics
Keys are stored as - keys that can be converted to or are stored without heap allocation. Otherwise a is allocated
Values are stored as - essentially a []

member.summary: provide a set of shared resources available via .
member.remarks:
In particular it provides a and a . The resources contained by a are designed for being reused to avoid expensive heap allocations when required. The intention is to use only a single instance within the whole application.
references are passed as a parameter to every constructor. If null it defaults to the instance. If an application needs to control the lifecycle of all shared resources it needs to create its own instance and pass it to the constructor to all instances it creates.
Access to shared resources is thread safe.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.DatabaseSchema
member.summary: A can be assigned to a to enable validation of entities represented as JSON used in write operations - create, upsert and patch.
member.remarks:
It is intended to be used for instances to ensure that the entities (records) in an always meet the expected type. So only successful validated JSON payloads are written to an . JSON validation includes the following checks:
Check if the type of a property matches the container entity type.
E.g. A container using a type 'Article' expect the property "name" of type string. { "id": "test", "name": 123 } will result in the error: WriteError: Article 'test', Incorrect type. was: 123, expect: string at Article > name
Check if required properties defined in the container type are present in the JSON payload.
E.g. A container using a type 'Article' requires the property "name" being present. { "id": "test" } will result in the error: WriteError: Article 'test', Missing required fields: [name] at Article > (root)
Check that no unknown properties are present in a JSON payload
E.g. A container using a type 'Article' expect only the properties 'id' and 'name'. { "id": "test", "name": "Phone", "foo": "Bar" } will result in the error: WriteError: Article 'test', Unknown property: 'foo' at Article > foo

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.Event.Collector.ChangeCombiner
member.summary: Combine container changes - create, upsert, merge and delete - stored in
member.remarks:
A is mainly used for optimization.
It combines multiple change tasks - eg. upsert - send from various clients into a single task.
This enables sending only a single tasks to subscribed clients instead of sending each change individually.
The effects are:
- size of serialized events sent to clients is smaller.
- serialized events are easier to read by humans.
- the CPU / memory cost to serialize events can reduce to O(1) instead O(N) for all clients having the same - See
is not thread safe.

member.summary: Add the monitor database to the given providing access information about of the Hub and its databases.
member.remarks:
Access information:
- request and task count executed per user
- request and task count executed per client. A user can access without, one or multiple client ids.
- events sent to (or buffered for) clients subscribed by these clients.
- aggregated access counts of the Hub in the last 30 seconds and 30 minutes.

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.HubExtensions.UseUserDB(Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.FlioxHub,Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.EntityDatabase,System.String,Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.DB.UserAuth.Users)
member.summary: Add the user_db database to the given to control individual user access to databases their containers and commands.
member.remarks:
- Each user has a set of roles stored in container permissions.
- Each role in container roles has a set of rights which grant or deny container access or command execution.
Requirement: the given must be created with the schema and the service instance. E.g.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Protocol.ProtocolMessage
member.summary: is the base type for all messages which are classified into request, response and event.
member.remarks:
A can also be used in communication going beyond the request / response schema. A is either one of the following types:
send by clients / received by hosts
send by hosts / received by clients
send by hosts / received by clients
Note: By applying this classification the protocol can also be used in peer-to-peer networking.
General principle of message protocol:
All messages like requests (their tasks), responses (their results) and events are stateless.
In other words: All messages are self-contained and doesn't (and must not) rely and previous sent messages. The technical aspect of having a connection e.g. HTTP or WebSocket is not relevant. This enables two fundamental features:
1. embedding all messages in various communication protocols like HTTP, WebSockets, TCP, WebRTC or datagram based protocols.
2. multiplexing of messages from different clients, servers or peers in a shared connection.
This also means all messages doesn't (and must not) require a session.
This principle also enables using a single by multiple clients like even for remote clients like .

member.name: F:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Protocol.ProtocolRequest.reqId
member.summary:
Used only for to enable:
1. Out of order response handling for their corresponding requests.
2. Multiplexing of requests and their responses for multiple clients e.g. using the same connection. This is not a common scenario but it enables using a single used by multiple clients.
The host itself only echos the to and does not utilize it internally.

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Protocol.Tasks.ReadEntitiesResult.ValidateEntities(Friflo.Json.Fliox.ShortString@,System.String,Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Host.SyncContext)
member.summary:
Validate all 's in the result set. Validation is required for all implementations which cannot ensure that the value of is valid JSON.
E.g. cannot ensure this, as the file content can be written or modified from external processes - for example by manually changing its JSON content with an editor.
A does not require validation as its key/values are always written via Fliox.Hub.Client library - which generate valid JSON.
So database adapters which can ensure the JSON value is always valid made calling obsolete - like Postgres/JSONB, Azure Cosmos DB or MongoDB.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Remote.Test.HttpFile
member.summary: is used to run multiple HTTP requests given in a simple text file used for concise regression tests
member.remarks:
The text file format is compatible to: REST Client - Visual Studio Marketplace
This approach enables request execution in multiple ways:
automated by unit tests
individually by using an IDE - e.g. the mentioned REST Client or Rider
Other benefits using this approach:
avoid flooding the test suite with primitive tests
simplify adjusting test results in case of behavior changes (e.g. bugfix or enhancements) by simplify committing the modified request response to version control.
avoid writing test assertions using difficult string literals caused by escaped characters or line feeds
This class is utilized by Friflo.Json.Tests.Common.UnitTest.Fliox.Remote.TestRemote to write a single output file for a given request file.
The generated output files are intended to be added to version control. The expectation is that after running the tests the output files are unmodified in version control (Git).
In case an output file is modified its new version have to be added to version control if the modifications meets expectation.

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Remote.HttpHost
member.summary: A enables remote access to databases, schemas and static web files via HTTP or WebSockets.
member.remarks:
The full feature set is listed at: Host README.md
In detail:
hosted databases are given by the passed via its constructor
exposed schemas are retrieved from the hosted databases
static web files are exposed by adding a using
A can be integrated by any HTTP server like like ASP.NET Core / Kestrel or the part of the .NET Base Class library (BCL).
A can be accessed remotely by:
Send Batch requests using a POST to ./fliox - containing multiple tasks
Send Batch requests containing multiple tasks via a WebSocket at ./fliox
REST API to POST, GET, PUT, DELETE and PATCH with via a path like ./fliox/rest/database/container/id
GraphQL via an endpoint like /fliox/graphql/database - requires package: Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.GraphQL

member.summary:
Central point where all Fliox related HTTP requests arrive. Each request is dispatched by a matching request handler.
Note: Request matching and execution are separated to ensure no heap allocation caused by awaited method calls.

member.summary: Serve static files in the given via HTTP by the given .
member.remarks:
Its main purpose is to add the static web files of the Hub Explorer.
As the Hub Explorer is optional and only required by server applications they are published in a separate nuget package https://www.nuget.org/packages/Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Explorer/
To add its files use:
httpHost.UseStaticFiles(HubExplorer.Path); // nuget: https://www.nuget.org/packages/Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Explorer

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Remote.SocketHost
member.summary:
Counterpart of used by socket implementations running on the server.
provide a set of methods to:
- parse serialized messages.
- execute 's and send serialized to client
is thread safe.
member.remarks:
The implementation aims to prevent head-of-line blocking.
Which means it supports out-of-order delivery for responses send to clients.
Special case
If enabling queueing request in head-of-line blocking can occur in case request execution is not 'instant'
Requests can be executed synchronous, asynchronous or on a specific thread / execution context.
- If is configured to queue requests they are executed on the thread calling
- Synchronous in case a request can be executed synchronous
- Asynchronous in case a request requires asynchronous execution

member.name: M:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Remote.WebSocketHost.RunReceiveMessageLoop
member.summary:
Loop is I/O bound and CPU bound (parse request, execute request, create response) => don't wrap in return Task.Run(async () => { ... });
As recommended in [... Don't Use Task.Run in the Implementation]
"They concluded that the best solution is to use an asynchronous signature but document the method clearly so that its CPU-bound nature will not be surprising"
See. [Should I expose asynchronous wrappers for synchronous methods? - .NET Parallel Programming] https://devblogs.microsoft.com/pfxteam/should-i-expose-asynchronous-wrappers-for-synchronous-methods
See: [Task.Run Etiquette Examples: Even in the Complex Case, Don't Use Task.Run in the Implementation] https://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/11/taskrun-etiquette-examples-even-in.html
See: [Task.Run Etiquette and Proper Usage] https://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/10/taskrun-etiquette-and-proper-usage.html

member.name: T:Friflo.Json.Fliox.Hub.Remote.WebSockets.FrameProtocolReader
member.summary:
WebSocket stream parser implemented using a final state machine.
Parses a WebSocket (without masking, message with length 208 bytes) stream with 2.5 GB/sec on a Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790K CPU 4.00GHz
member.remarks:
Objectives of implementation:
- Support returning only a single byte at all states
- Maximize memory locality by using a fixed size
- Minimize calls to
- Minimize conditions. Especially in hot loops e.g. when reading the payload
- Minimize heap allocations. The only allocations are
the Task when calling
the Task when calling no more bytes left ro read in
